div1.head: Memorandum for Wade Hampton Frost, August 24, 1930
div1.p:
Memorandum
(for W. H. F.)
August 24, 1930. Acknowledgements
To

list.item:
1) Dr. Herbert Putnam, Librarian, of the Library of Congress, for the
unusual facilities and generous assistance given us by him-
himself and his staff. In this connection special thanks are
due to
a) Mr. Charles Martel, Chief of the Catalogue Division for placing
His vast bibliographical knowledge at our disposal. (Mem. Dr.
Martel is the leading cataloguer in the world)
b) Mr. Martin Roberts, Superintendent of the Reading Room, for the
unusual facilities afforded us in the use of reference books.
cc) Colonel Lawrence Martin, Chief of the Division of Maps, for his
advice and help in the preparation of the maps included in
this book.
d) Miss Frances Grace Brown, of the Catalogue Division, to whom
the Bibliography, as a Bibliography is due. See letter of
transmittal for details, with which, however, you are already
familiar.

2) Colonel P. M. Ashburn, Librarian, of the Army Medical Library (its
latest title, gotten from Col. A.) and to his staff for the
generous help and unusual facilities afforded us in the use
of reference books and periodicals. (Mem. Colonel Ashburn
gave Miss Brown and myself passes for nights, Sundays and
holidays, without which it would have been impossible to check
all of our references during the summer of 1928, as Miss Brown
and I had to do most of our work before and after hours on ac-
count of the intense heat and her regular work at the Library of
Congress. I should like to mention Colonel Garrison by name,
but, although he showed great interest and offered to help us
we only showed him one reference, that of Corre, re the Kordofan
Brigade. Indeed, Colonel Ashburn showed it to him, and told us
what Garrison said of the ref., after which Ashburn decided also
that Corre's account was ambiguous, as Garrison had already done.

3) Miss Margaret Doonan, Librarian, of the Library of the U. S. Public
Health Service, for valued assistance in placing at our disposal
the books and periodicals of this Library. (Mem. We got some
things at the P. H. S. Library we could find nowhere else, among
them Balfour's survey of Mauritius.

4) Colonel Frederick F. Russell, Director, International Health Division
of the Rockefeller Foundation, and staff.

5) Mr. H. B. van Wesep,
Chief, Information Service, The Rockefeller Foundation.

6) Dr. Edwards (British Museum) Mem. You have his letter, re Aedes
(Stegomyia) aegypti being Old World form, with his initials,
which it would take me too long to look up)
7) Dr. L. O. Howard, Principal Entomologist, Bureau of Entomology.
8) Dr. J. Martinez Hernandez, of Mérida, Yucatan.

9) Dr. Sylvanus Griswold Morley,
Associate in Middle American Archaeology.
Carnegie Institution of Washington, D. C.

div1.p:
Mem. If you think, from the correspondence in your pos-
session, that Dr. Spinden should also receive acknowledgement for
his data re things Mayan etc. His ref. would be

Dr. Herbert J. Spinden,
Peabody Museum,
Cambridge, Mass.

I hardly think it worth while to include him, however, not that, of
course, is up to you, as is also the rearrangement both in language
and sequence of the above material.

Acknowledgement will also have to be made, by publishers of Carter's
book, to those from whom they receive permission to reproduce illus-
trative material (photostats, tracings etc.) used in the book, of
which a partial list is enclosed. This, of course is does not apply
to our three maps, which are specially drawn for the book.
